newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria's 1996 privatisations totalled 96 bln lev.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria's 1996 privatisations totalled 96 bln lev.

text.p: Bulgaria completed privatisation deals worth 95.93 billion levs for 509 enterprises in 1996 and plans to concentrate on fewer, higher-value deals in 1997, the privatisation agency said on Sunday.

Of the total 1996 privatisation income, 41 billion levs represented direct payments, and 46.7 billion was companies' debt which was taken on by buyers, the agency's director Vesselin Blagoev told a news conference.
Bulgaria badly needs income from privatisation to meet payments on its $10 billion foreign debt. Central bank reserves declined to $525 million at end-November from $1.408 billion a year earlier.
The deals were carried out both by the agency and by government ministries and committees. A total of 309 deals were concluded in 1995.

Blagoev said the buyers had agreed to invest more than 30 billion levs in privatised companies. "This sum is vitally important for our economy as it is clear that the state cannot afford to invest that in domestic production," he said.
He said a tender procedure for the sale of a 60 percent stake in chemical firm Chimco would be opened in mid-January.

On December 19, Belgian chemicals company Solvay SA said it had signed a preliminary agreement with the privatisation agency allowing it to acquire 60 percent of soda ash producer Sodi for $160 million.
The main deal expected next year is the sale of a 25 percent stake in Bulgarian Telecommunications Company to an international operator.
The government has shortlisted six banks of those who applied to advise it on the deal and has said it will make its choice by the end of January.
